hints_html:
We need to relate the angle with the x and y coordinates. Try using

\(\displaystyle \tan(\theta) = \frac{y(t)}{x(t)}\)
hints_latex:
We need to relate the angle with the \emph{x} and \emph{y} coordinates.
Try using

$\displaystyle \tan(\theta) = \frac{y(t)}{x(t)}$
hints_raw:
We need to relate the angle with the ''x'' and ''y'' coordinates. Try using

<math> \displaystyle \tan(\theta) = \frac{y(t)}{x(t)}</math>
question: 7 (iii)
sols_html:
Notice that

\(\displaystyle \tan(\theta) = \frac{y(t)}{x(t)}\)

Taking derivatives with respect to time gives

\(\displaystyle \sec^{2}(\theta)\frac{d\theta}{dt} = \frac{\frac{dy}{dt}\cdot x(t) - \frac{dx}{dt} \cdot y(t)}{x(t)^{2}}\)

From the previous parts, we have that

\(\displaystyle \frac{dx}{dt}\bigg|_{x=2} = 2\)

and we are given that

\(\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dt}\bigg|_{x=2} = 8\)

and so plugging in the point \(\displaystyle (x(t),y(t)) = (2,4)\) into the triangle, we see that

\(\displaystyle \sec(\theta) = \frac{1}{\cos(\theta)} = \frac{1}{\frac{2}{\sqrt{2^{2} + 4^{2}}}} = \frac{\sqrt{20}}{2} = \sqrt{5}\)

Using all this information, we plug in the point \(\displaystyle (2,4)\) and see that

\[\begin{aligned} \sec^{2}(\theta)\frac{d\theta}{dt} &= \frac{\frac{dy}{dt}\cdot x(t) - \frac{dx}{dt} \cdot y(t)}{x(t)^{2}} \\ (\sqrt{5})^{2}\frac{d\theta}{dt} &= \frac{(8)(2) - (2)(4)}{(2)^{2}} \\ 5\frac{d\theta}{dt} &= 2 \\ \frac{d\theta}{dt} &= \frac{2}{5} \end{aligned}\]

and this completes the question.
sols_latex:
Notice that

$\displaystyle \tan(\theta) = \frac{y(t)}{x(t)}$

Taking derivatives with respect to time gives

$\displaystyle \sec^{2}(\theta)\frac{d\theta}{dt} = \frac{\frac{dy}{dt}\cdot x(t) - \frac{dx}{dt} \cdot y(t)}{x(t)^{2}}$

From the previous parts, we have that

$\displaystyle \frac{dx}{dt}\bigg|_{x=2} = 2$

and we are given that

$\displaystyle \frac{dy}{dt}\bigg|_{x=2} = 8$

and so plugging in the point $\displaystyle (x(t),y(t)) = (2,4)$ into
the triangle, we see that

$\displaystyle \sec(\theta) = \frac{1}{\cos(\theta)} = \frac{1}{\frac{2}{\sqrt{2^{2} + 4^{2}}}} = \frac{\sqrt{20}}{2} = \sqrt{5}$

Using all this information, we plug in the point $\displaystyle (2,4)$
and see that

\begin{align*}
\sec^{2}(\theta)\frac{d\theta}{dt} &= \frac{\frac{dy}{dt}\cdot x(t) - \frac{dx}{dt} \cdot y(t)}{x(t)^{2}} \\
 (\sqrt{5})^{2}\frac{d\theta}{dt} &= \frac{(8)(2) - (2)(4)}{(2)^{2}} \\
 5\frac{d\theta}{dt} &= 2 \\
\frac{d\theta}{dt} &= \frac{2}{5} 
\end{align*}

and this completes the question.
sols_raw:
Notice that

<math> \displaystyle \tan(\theta) = \frac{y(t)}{x(t)}</math>

Taking derivatives with respect to time gives

<math> \displaystyle \sec^{2}(\theta)\frac{d\theta}{dt} = \frac{\frac{dy}{dt}\cdot x(t) - \frac{dx}{dt} \cdot y(t)}{x(t)^{2}}</math>

From the previous parts, we have that

<math> \displaystyle \frac{dx}{dt}\bigg|_{x=2} = 2</math>

and we are given that

<math> \displaystyle \frac{dy}{dt}\bigg|_{x=2} = 8</math>

and so plugging in the point <math> \displaystyle (x(t),y(t)) = (2,4)</math> into the triangle, we see that

<math> \displaystyle \sec(\theta) = \frac{1}{\cos(\theta)} = \frac{1}{\frac{2}{\sqrt{2^{2} + 4^{2}}}} = \frac{\sqrt{20}}{2} = \sqrt{5} </math>

Using all this information, we plug in the point <math> \displaystyle (2,4) </math> and see that

<math> \begin{align}
 \sec^{2}(\theta)\frac{d\theta}{dt} &= \frac{\frac{dy}{dt}\cdot x(t) - \frac{dx}{dt} \cdot y(t)}{x(t)^{2}} \\
 (\sqrt{5})^{2}\frac{d\theta}{dt} &= \frac{(8)(2) - (2)(4)}{(2)^{2}} \\
 5\frac{d\theta}{dt} &= 2 \\
\frac{d\theta}{dt} &= \frac{2}{5} \\
\end{align}
</math>

and this completes the question.
statement_html:
A particle is moving in the (x,y)-plane along the curve \(y = x^{2}\). As it passes through the point P = (2, 4), its y coordinate changes at a rate of 8 units/sec.

iii) What is the rate of change of the angle \(\theta\) between the positive x-axis and the line connecting the origin and the particle?
statement_latex:
A particle is moving in the (x,y)-plane along the curve $y = x^{2}$. As
it passes through the point P = (2, 4), its y coordinate changes at a
rate of 8 units/sec.

iii) What is the rate of change of the angle $\theta$ between the
positive x-axis and the line connecting the origin and the particle?

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH102/December_2011/MATH102_2011_7ii.png}
statement_raw:
A particle is moving in the (x,y)-plane along the curve <math>y = x^{2}</math>. As it passes through
the point P = (2, 4), its y coordinate changes at a rate of 8 units/sec.

iii) What is the rate of change of the angle <math>\theta</math> between the positive x-axis and the
line connecting the origin and the particle?

[[File:MATH102 2011 7ii.png]]
